key_points: Niviane Petit Phelps, a nurse at Jackson Memorial Hospital, was arrested for threatening to kill U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris.
Phelps allegedly recorded and sent videos to her imprisoned husband, in which she expressed her hatred for President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris.
A total of five videos and two photographs were sent, with the videos each being 30 seconds long.
In the videos, Phelps made direct threats against Vice President Harris, including a promise of violence and death.
Phelps used JPay, a communication app for those incarcerated, to send the videos to her husband.
Phelps was seen at a shooting range in photographs dated Feb. 20, 2021, and she applied for a concealed weapons permit two days later.
Phelps' mother appealed to the president and vice president for forgiveness, suggesting her daughter did not mean the threats.
Jackson Health System has suspended Phelps without pay and is processing her employment termination.
Phelps told investigators she was angry about Kamala Harris becoming vice president but is 'over it now'.
Threatening government officials of the United States is a felony offense, potentially leading to up to five years in federal prison.
